texts.shortText: Oxystele variegata (now split into O. antoni and O. impervia)

Shell medium-sized, globular and winkle-shaped, with a fairly short, blunt spire. External colour extremely variable, but typically tabby patterned, with oblique dotted bands running across a yellowish or greenish background. There is often a band of larger, more distinct alternating black and pale markings around the top of the last whorl. Inner surface pearly; umbilicus closed, operculum round and horny.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to far Eastern Cape.

Very common species in the mid to low intertidal of rocky shores, where it is an important grazer. Previously known as O. variegata, but that species has recently been shown to comprise a mixture of two very similar species, O. antoni and O. impervia. Since research on the biology precedes the split, it is assumed here that both the new species share the same biological characteristics.

Juveniles occur mostly in the lower intertidal and are restricted to that zone because they are unable to survive the hotter, dryer condition further upshore. As they grow, they tend to migrate further upshore to avoid predation by whelks, which is most intense at lower levels. They do this despite the fact that food is more readily available at lower levels. Growth is initially quite rapid, a size of 14 mm being attained in the first year, but this only increases to 18 mm after the second year (growth rates also vary with tidal level, becoming slower at upper levels). Commonly fed on by various predators including starfish, whelks and intertidal fish.
Feeds on encrusting algae and microalgae on intertidal and shallow subtidal rocks.

Sexes are separate and the sex ratio does not differ significantly from 1:1. Spawning appears to take place throughout the year. The eggs are released into the water column and larval development takes place in the plankton.

Several common species of Oxystele co-exist on the same Cape shores. The Beaded topshells (O. impervia) is extremely similar and difficult to distinguish (although genetic work has shown it to be distinct), but it has bead-like rows of dots that spiral around the whorls. The Tiger topshell (O. tigrina) and Pink lipped topshell (O. sinensis) are both much larger with a plain black exterior and, in the latter case, a pink interior.
